Graphical abstract WO3/TiO2(WTi) composite was prepared via an environmentally friendly, fast and facile wet impregnation method using distilled water as the solvent. The catalyst composite was investigated by in-situ XPS-UPS and ex-situ BET and XRD characterization techniques before and after the activation under hydrogen flow. The activation of the composite resulted in the formation of metallic and acidic catalytic sites in the form of WO3-x(OH)y on the surface of the WTi composite. The distribution of these sites depends on the activation temperature. XPS results show the formation of a different oxidation state of tungsten after its activation. The formation of WO3-x with metallic properties was confirmed by an examination of the density of states in the valence band region. On the other hand, the Brønsted acidic sites were attributed to the OH group observed in the XPS peak fitting of the O1 s peak at 531.4 eV. The catalytic activity was evaluated for the hydroisomerization/hydrocracking of n-hexane and n-heptane using 15 cm3 WTi in a large-scale reactor at different experimental parameters. At a reaction temperature of 598 K, the catalytic activity was 97.1% in the case of n-heptane in favor of β-scission (C3-iC4, 78.4%), compared to 76.1% activity in favor of the isomerization products (84.6%) in the case of n-hexane after the composite activation at 673 K. The research octane number (RON) was improved from 24.8 for n-hexane to the 70–80 range for hexane isomers and from zero in the case of n-heptane to cracking products with a high octane number. Upon increasing the activation temperature to 773 K, the hydrogenolysis of n-heptane was the dominant catalytic reaction. Keywords WO3-x(OH)y XPS-UPS Bifunctional catalyst n-Hexane n-Heptane RON 1 Introduction Since tetraethyl lead and aromatic additives are restricted in gasoline production for environmental protection, branched alkanes have been used to improve the gasoline octane number [1]. The hydroisomerization of linear alkanes to corresponding branched isomers and hydrocracking to small fractions are essential processes in petroleum technologies for the production of gasoline with a high octane number. These processes depend on the catalyst structure, alkane molecular weight, reaction temperature, pressure, and other parameters that can affect the catalytic reaction pathway. Bifunctional (metal-acid) sites are required for the hydroisomerization process, whereas monofunctional sites are sufficient for the hydrocracking process under hydrogen flow. There are two types of cracking processes: hydrogenolysis and β-scission. The former is a metal-catalyzed reaction, while the latter is an acid-catalyzed reaction (i.e., Brønsted acid) [2]. The possible catalytic reaction pathways of n-hexane and n-heptane in the presence of metallic (M) and acidic (A) sites are illustrated in Scheme 1 . The catalytic reaction pathway depends on the M/A ratio and the strength of each site. Commercially, Pt supported on acidic chlorinated alumina or zeolite are the most commonly used catalysts in hydroisomerization reactions [2,3], and acidic zeolite is utilized in the hydrocracking reactions [4,5]. Despite the higher yields of branched products at low operating temperatures, these catalysts are very sensitive to poisons, such as sulfur compounds or water, which are usually present in oil derivatives and cause severe corrosion and pollution problems. To address these problems, it is essential to discover and optimize new low-cost, earth-abundant, highly stable and easy to handle solid multifunctional catalysts in order to perform hydroisomerization/hydrocracking reactions at low temperature. Tungsten oxide based-catalysts have been widely used and investigated as a solid acid catalyst for many applications such as dehydration of alcohols, hydroisomerization of alkane and alkene, metathesis of 1-hexene, electrochemistry, and photocatalysis [6–13]. A unique property of WO3 is its reducibility to WO3-x, producing a considerable amount of oxygen vacancies and providing the tungsten oxide with some electrical conductivity and electron donor density [14]. Katrib et al. reported that the partial reduction of WO3 under hydrogen flow resulted in the formation of WO2 with metallic properties due to the presence of free electrons in the 5d and 6 s orbitals at the Fermi level, as observed in the XPS valence band region using the density of states. Dissociated hydrogen gas on the surface of WO2 generates Brønsted acid sites, and thus bifunctional sites were generated. It was also mentioned that the formation of a bifunctional active phase on WO3 required a high reduction temperature of 773 K [15–17]. To the best of our knowledge, most of the studies on W-based catalysts were carried out using small amounts of catalyst (0.1–1 g) in small-scale reactors using a metal with strong acid support such as Al2O3, SiO2, and ZrO2 [18–21]. In this study, WTi catalyst was of interest because WO3 and TiO2 are earth-abundant and inexpensive compared to Pt-based catalysts. Moreover, the low acidic property of the TiO2 pellet was attractive due to its stability under high temperature its ability to support the catalyst with mechanical strength for easy handling. A large-scale reactor loaded with 15 cm3 of catalyst was used under different experimental conditions to optimize the performance of the catalyst in order to simulate hydroisomerization/hydrocracking reactions under industrial conditions. 2 Experiment 2.1 Catalyst preparation The composite was prepared via the wet impregnation method using distilled water (DW) as the solvent. The calculated amount (3.34 g) of ammonium metatungstate hydrate (NH4)6H2W12O40·xH2O (99.9%), supplied by Strem Chemicals and equivalent to 5 monolayers of tungsten trioxide (WO3), was dissolved in 50 mL of DW. Then, the solution was poured into a 10 g P-25 TiO2 pellet (obtained from Degussa in a cylindrical shape with the average dimensions of 4.3 × 1.7 mm with the pore volume of 0.5 cm3/g and the BET surface area of 50 ± 5 m2/g). This mixture was heated to 343 K under vacuum and rotated at 250 rpm in a Rotavapor to remove the excess water. The composite was dried in an oven at 383 K for 6 h. Finally, the composite was introduced into a tube furnace for calcination under a flow of air with a temperature ramping of 10 K/min to reach 773 K and was maintained at 773 K for 12 h. The composite was designated WTi, where W = WO3 and Ti = TiO2. 2.2 Characterization techniques The BET surface area was evaluated using a surface area analyzer (Gemini-V, Micrometrics, USA) at the boiling point of liquid nitrogen (196 K). Small amounts of composites (100–300 mg) were degassed in a VacuPrep061 sample degassing system at a temperature of 110 °C for 3 h prior to starting the experiments. Surface areas were calculated using the Brunauer–Emmet–Teller model for the isotherms. For all composites, nitrogen gas of 99.999% purity was used as the adsorbate. The composite was activated first at the atmospheric pressure in a quartz microreactor at 623 K, 673 K, 723 K and 773 K each for 14 h under the hydrogen flow of 200 mL/min was then transferred to BET for measurements. XPS-UPS spectra were recorded on a Thermo Scientific ESCALAB 250Xi spectrometer (UK), using Al Kα radiation (1486.6 eV) for XPS and a He(I) resonance of 58.4 nm radiation of 21.217 eV for UPS. The spectra acquisition and handling were carried out using an online Avantage 4.5 data system (UK). The investigated sample was fixed on the sample holder as prepared in an ambient atmosphere and then mounted and stored in the preparation chamber until a vacuum below 1.0 × 10−7 bar was reached. Then, the sample was transferred to an analysis chamber at 1.0 × 10−9 bar and was exposed to X-ray radiation (XPS) or UV radiation (UPS) for a certain number of scans. After the data acquisition, the sample was transferred into a high-pressure gas cell built-in a preparation chamber with a maximum temperature and pressure of 773 K and 5 bar, respectively. For WTi activation, a flow of 200 mL/min hydrogen was introduced at 5 bar and 623 K for 14 h. The sample was reintroduced into the analysis chamber at the appropriate vacuum. This process was repeated for the activation temperature of 673 K, 723 K and 773 K. All binding energy values (BE/eV) were determined with respect to the contaminated C (1s) line at 284.6 eV. The 1 s binding energy of oxygen, as well as W4f (7/2 and 5/2) binding energies, were taken into consideration for the assignment of different states obtained before and after the activation process. All binding energies were reported within the experimental error of ± 0.2 eV. X-ray diffraction patterns were obtained using a SIEMENS D5000 diffractometer (Germany) equipped with Ni-filtered CuKα radiation (λ = 15.418 x−2 nm). The diffractometer was operated at 40 kV and 30 mA. The data were acquired in the range between 10° and 80° with the divergence slit of 1° and controlled by an online microcomputer. The catalyst composite was activated first at the atmospheric pressure in a quartz microreactor at 623 K, 673 K, 723 K, and 773 K each for 14 h under the hydrogen flow of 200 mL/min and was then transferred to XRD for measurement. For phase identification purposes, the automatic JCPDS library search and match was adopted. The computer Standard SEARCH and DIFFRACT AT software (Australia) packages were used. 2.3 Reactor design To simulate the industrial catalytic process, a large-scale catalyst testing unit supplied by Xytel India was used in this study. This unit is equipped with two input gas lines. The first line controlled with a mass flow meter for the hydrogen gas flow in the range of 0–100 standard liters per hour (SLPH). The second gas line was used for nitrogen to pressurize the feed tank. The reactant was transferred to the catalyst zone via the feed tank attached to a high-pressure liquid pump in the range of 0.2–3.4 mL/min for the transfer of the reactants to the catalyst zone. The reactant evaporated in the preheated zone at 473 K and mixed with hydrogen before the catalyst zone. The catalytic test unit has a fixed-bed stain steel catalytic reactor with the total volume of 200 cm3. This reactor was divided into three zones that were thermally controlled with three K-type thermocouples with a maximum working temperature of 823 K. The tested catalyst was loaded into the middle zone, while the upper and lower zones were filled with inert alumina balls without any catalytic activity, as reported previously [22,23]. The catalyst unit was controlled by a back-pressure valve with a maximum working pressure of 50 bar. After the catalytic reaction occurs, the products flow through two pathways, with one pathway going to a condenser cooled with a circulated chiller for liquid output products and the second self-heated path attached to online Shimadzu gas chromatography (GC-2014) instrument controlled with a manual gas sampler. 2.4 Reaction procedures and analysis The steps for experimental reaction procedure and analysis are as follows: 1) Composite loading process – 15 cm3 ≈ 16.5 g of WTi composite was mixed with 60 cm3 alumina balls and loaded into the middle zone of the reactor. The lower and upper zones were filled with 75 cm3 alumina balls for each zone and were separated from the middle zone with glass wool. Then, the catalyst loaded the catalytic unit was pressurized by H2 at 15 bar, and all connected points were checked for leaks with a high leak detector solution. Then, the catalyst unit was depressurized, and H2 gas was removed completely. 2) Catalyst composite activation process – the loaded composite was first heated at 437 K for 1 h to remove any surface adsorbed water; then, a hydrogen valve was opened at 30 SLPH, and the temperature was gradually increased from 437 K to 773 K at an increment of 50 K/h. While the temperature was raised, the pressure was slowly increased and set at 15 bar with the back pressure valve control. Finally, the composite was kept at 623 K, 673 K, 723 K or 773 K under a hydrogen flow of 30 SLPH and 15 bar overnight. The activated catalyst composites were designated WTi-623, WTi-673, WTi-723 and WTi-773 where 623, 673, 723 and 773 are the activation temperatures. 3) Reactant flow – the reactants n-hexane (C6) or n-heptane (C7) were pumped into the reactor through a calibrated high-pressure liquid pump at a rate of 0.2-0.5 mL/min. The catalytic reactions tests were performed on activated catalyst composites at different reaction temperatures, different hydrogen flows, different LHSV and different pressures to determine the best catalytic reaction conditions. 4) GC analysis – the catalytic reaction products were analyzed with online GC equipped with a Petrocol-DH column (100 m × 0.25 mm ID) and a flame ionization detector. The peaks in the chromatograms obtained from the GC were identified using standard solutions and the table supplied with the column. The research octane number (RON) for the final product in each catalytic experiment was calculated as [1]: R O N = Σ i = 1 K y i R O N i where RON i is the research octane number of each pure component (i) [24] in the final product, and y i is the mole fraction of molecule i. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization The average surface areas of TiO2 and WTi composites before and after activation are shown in Table 1 . As seen in Table 1, the loading of WO3 on TiO2 reduces the surface area from 50.1 m2 g−1 for bare TiO2 to 37.7 m2 g−1 for WTi. This could be attributed to the filling of some pores of TiO2 by WO3. The changes in the BET surface area for the composites after activation were not noticeable. This reflects the high dispersion of WO3 on TiO2 after the activation. XPS survey spectra of the calcinated WTi composite shows three significant elements W, Ti and O and a low percentage of C. This confirmed that all ammonium metatungstate salt was converted to tungsten oxide W6+ in the form of WO3 (Fig. 1 ). In-situ activation of WTi by hydrogen flow at 623 K for 14 h results in the formation of the different oxidation states of W (W6+, W5+, W4+, Wx+ and W00), as observed in the XPS curve fitting of the W4f region (Fig. 2 ). The Wx+ is an oxidation state of tungsten with the binding energy between those of W4+ and W00 [25]. Increasing the activation temperature to 673 K, 723 K, and 773 K did not change the W oxidation states. However, considerable improvements in the atomic percentage of W4+, Wx+ and W00 were observed, as shown in Table 2 and Fig. 2. The formation of oxidation states in the form of WO3-x (3 ≥ x > 0) on the surface of activated WTi generates free electrons in the 5d and 6 s atomic orbitals responsible for the metallic properties of the catalyst composite. This was confirmed by the density of states at the Fermi level in the XPS valence band region (Fig. 4). The formation of W4+ in the form of WO2 with the metallic character was confirmed by UPS spectra as the density of states at the Fermi level with maxima at 0.7 and 2.2 eV (Fig. 3 ) corresponding to the ϭ and π bonds [6,15,26,27]. The XPS curve fitting of the O1 s region for WTi before and after the activation (Table 2 and Fig. 5 ) shows the presence of two oxygen peaks. The major peak at 530.5 eV was mostly due to the oxide oxygen in tungsten oxides or titanium oxide and the small shoulder peak at 531.2 eV could be attributed to the Brønsted acidic (OH) sites [6,15,16,28]. The Brønsted OH peak prior to the activation may be formed from residual water during the calcination process [29]. It is important to mention that the chemical or electronic structure of TiO2 did not change during the activation process (Fig. 6 and Table 2). XPS quantitative analysis shows a partial reduction of WO3 to WO3-x. The degree of reduction of WO3 increases from 0 to 47.5 and 64.0% as the activation temperature is increased from room temperature to 623 K and 673 K, respectively (Table 3 ), leading to an increase in the metallic sites fraction (M) from 0 to 4.8 and 6.3%. Additionally, the fraction of the Brønsted acidic (A) sites prior to the activation was 14.9% and then increased to 19.4% and 18.4%. Therefore, both metallic and acidic sites increase with increasing activation temperatures, but more metallic sites are formed compared to the acidic sites, as could be seen from the M/A ratio. The M/A ratio increases from 0 before activation to 0.25 and 0.34 after the activation at 623 K and 673 K, respectively. However, increasing the activation temperature to 723 K and 773 K result in a drastic decrease in the acidic sites with slight increase in metallic sites. Consequently, the M/A ratio increases sharply to 0.62 and 0.96 at 723 K and 773 K, respectively. In summary, the activation of WTi with the hydrogen flow results in the creation of metallic sites on the surface of the WTi composite, converting it from a monofunctional acidic catalyst to a bifunctional catalyst. Ex-situ XRD measurements of the WTi catalyst composite before and after the activation with hydrogen are presented jointly in Fig. 7 . The XRD patterns show only three phases: the two phases of anatase and rutile TiO2 and one phase of monoclinic WO3. No changes were observed in the TiO2 phases after the activation at 623 K, 673 K, 723 K and 773 K supporting the XPS results. Slight decreases in the intensities of the WO3 patterns were found upon increasing the activation temperature up to 673 K and completely disappeared at 723 K and 773 K. The XRD pattern for WO3-x oxides was not observed, unlike the WO3-x feature detected in the XPS spectra; this could be attributed to the re-oxidation of the activated sample upon its exposure to air during the handling and crushing compared to the in-situ study in the case of XPS. 3.2 Catalytic reaction of n-hexane 3.2.1 Effect of activation/reaction temperature Combining the XPS results of the changes in the metallic/acidic ratio of the composite after its activation with the results of its catalytic reaction helps to deduce the best activation/reaction conditions for a specific reaction. The hydroisomerization/hydrocracking process enables the conversion of n-hexane with RON = 24.6 to isomers or cracking products with a higher octane number to be used in gasoline production. The catalytic activity of the WTi composite was tracked at diverse activation/reaction temperatures under a hydrogen flow of 30 SLPH and 15 bar for the hydroisomerization/hydrocracking of n-hexane at 0.8 h−1 LHSV with a 14.6H2/HC molar ratio. The catalytic reaction results are presented in Table 4 . Activation of WTi at 623 K shows 84.1% conversion, 29.1% isomerization selectivity, 44.5% β-scission, and 26.4% hydrogenolysis at the reaction temperature of 623 K. This conversion decreases to 50.4% with the increase in the isomerization to 62.9% at 598 K. When the activation temperature was increased to 673 K, the isomerization selectivity increased to 58.9% at 623 K compared to 29.1% isomerization products obtained from the activated catalyst at 623 K. On the other hand, the conversion improved to 76.1% with the high isomerization selectivity of 84.6% with a low amount of total cracking products (15.3%) at 598 K compared to 50.4% conversion at the same temperature after the activation at 623 K. The higher amount of C3 at the activation/reaction temperature of 623 K could be attributed to the large accessibility of the Brønsted acid sites and low M/A ratio, where the β-scission cracking reaction pathway is more favorable for the iC6 carbenium ion intermediate (Scheme 1). The catalytic activity of WTi decreases drastically upon its activation at 723 K and 773 K, in which case the hydrogenolysis products (C1-C5) are the main products. This catalytic behavior could be attributed to the increases of the metallic sites as observed from Table 3. The total RON of products decreased from 102.3 to 68.9 at 673 K and 598 K, respectively, after the activation at 673 K due to the considerable amounts of C1-C3 cracking products with higher RON (i.e., C1 = 120, C2 = 114.9 and C3 = 111) compared to the RON of isomer products (i.e., 2 MP = 73.4, 3 MP = 74.5, 2.2 DMB = 91.8 and 2.3 DMB = 104.3) (Table 4). These catalytic results are in good agreement with the XPS results in which the activation of WTi with hydrogen at 673 K for 14 h resulted in the creation of highly stable bifunctional sites on the surface of WTi in the form of WO3-x (OH) y. 3.2.2 Effect of hydrogen flow rate The effect of the hydrogen flow rate on the catalytic performances of activated WTi at 673 K was studied for the hydroisomerization/hydrocracking of n-hexane under the hydrogen pressure of 15 bar and 0.8 h−1 LHSV at different reaction temperatures to optimize the working conditions at low hydrogen flow and low temperature, which is essential for industrial applications. Changing the hydrogen flow rate from 5 to 30 SLPH, the H2/HC molar ratios were varied from 2.4 to 14.6 under the constant n-hexane flow rate of 0.2 mL/min. At the reaction temperature of 598 K, when the hydrogen flow drops from 30 to 15 SLPH, a slight increase in the conversion of n-hexane was observed (from 72.9 to 79.0%) accompanied with the drop of isomerization selectively from 90.6% to 83.5%. The same behavior was observed at 588 K (Table 5 ). The major isomerization products are 2 MP, 3 MP, 2.2 DMB, and 2.2 DMB with a total RON of approximately 71.0. The catalytic activity at 598 K, hydrogen flow 25 SLPH at 12.2H2/HC molar ratio seems to be the same as that at 588 K, 15 SLPH at 7.3H2/HC molar ratio. The same behavior was observed when the temperature/hydrogen flow decreases from 588 K/10 SLPH to 578 K/5 SLPH. This catalytic behavior could be attributed to the effect of the temperature and contact time between the n-hexane and the active sites on the surface of activated WTi. It seems that the decrease of hydrogen flow rate leads to the increase the contact time of n-hexane with active sites. Based on these results, the hydrogen flow at 5 SLPH and the reaction temperature at 598 K are used in the subsequent experiments to study the catalytic performances of WO3-x(OH)y towards n-hexane at various parameters. 3.2.3 Effect of liquid hourly space velocity (LHSV) Liquid hourly space velocity (LHSV) is calculated from the volume of the reactant per volume of catalyst per hour (v/v/h). In the light naphtha reforming process, the LHSV is varied from 1.0 to 3.0 h−1 [30]. To optimize the catalytic performance of n-hexane on activated WTi, different amounts of n-hexane were introduced corresponding to LHSV values in the 0.8–2.0 h−1 range, while other experimental parameters were kept constant (5 SLPH, 15 bar, and 598 K). There is hardly any change in the catalytic activity (approximately 83.0%) with a slight decline in the isomerization selectivity observed by changing the LHSV value from 0.8 to 2.0 h−1. This result indicates that activated WTi has sufficient active sites on its surface to convert most of the n-hexane molecules. On the other hand, the increases in the cracking selectivity of 42.0% at 2.0 h−1 LHSV of 1.0H2/HC molar ratio in favor of C3 (23.0%) could be attributed to the β-scission of the iC6 carbenium ions formed on the acidic sites at low hydrogen flow; see Scheme 1. It is important to note that at all LHSV values, the 2 MP/3 MP ratio remains constant at 1.5; this demonstrates that n-hexane hydroisomerization reaction mechanism occurs on a well-defined and stable bifunctional WO3-X (OH) y phase. Furthermore, the total RON of the catalytic reaction products, including n-hexane, remains constant at 78.0 (Fig. 8 ) 3.2.4 Effect of hydrogen pressure To explore the effect of hydrogen pressure on the catalytic performance of activated WTi, changes of the hydrogen pressure from 5 to 25 bar were studied while keeping other reaction parameters constant at the best conditions of 2.0 h−1 LHSV, 5 SLPH, H2/HC = 1 and reaction temperature of 598 K. As readily seen in Table 6 , approximately the same conversion of 80.0% was observed as the hydrogen pressure was increased from 10 to 25 bar while the isomerization selectivity decreased from 61.0% to 49.9%. At 5 bar, the conversion decreases sharply to 64.4% with an isomerization selectivity of 68.0% and cracking selectivity of 32.0%. The best reaction hydrogen pressure on the activated WTi regarding the conversion and isomerization selectivity based on the obtained results is 15 bar. In this case, methyl hexanes and dimethylbutanes are the isomers products and high octane numbers of branched products iC4-iC5 were also observed. Moreover, the calculated RON of the catalytic reaction products shows high octane number values in the range of 64.5–78.8. 3.2.5 Catalytic stability of active phase The most important factor in the industrial refining process is the resistance of the catalyst active phases to carbon poisoning after exposure to hydrocarbons for an extended time. Based on the above results, the best activation conditions are 673 K, 30 SLPH, and 15 bar for 14 h, and the best catalytic reaction conditions in terms of conversion are the reaction temperature of 598 K, 5 SLPH, 15 bar, 2.0 h−1 LHSV, and H2/HC molar ratio = 1. Therefore, the catalytic stability on WTi was studied at conditions where the reaction was carried out at the lowest reaction temperature, lowest hydrogen flow, and largest feed of n-hexane. As observed in Fig. 9 , there is no noticeable change in the catalytic activity ≈80.0%, isomerization selectivity ≈60.0% and cracking ≈ 40.0% with the same product distribution and total RON of ≈75. Moreover, these catalytic results confirm the high stability and carbon poisoning resistance of WO3-x (OH) y bifunctional sites created on the surface of the activated WTi catalyst composites at 673 K for 14 h by hydrogen. 3.3 Catalytic reaction results of n-heptane 3.3.1 Effect of activation/reaction temperature Hydroisomerization of n-heptane via the bifunctional mechanism required weak acidic functionalities, while strong acidic functionalities are required for n-hexane. To elucidate the active sites formed on the activated WTi and the effect of these sites on the catalytic reaction pathway of n-heptane, 0.2 mL/min of n-heptane was introduced on 15 cm3 of activated WTi at different activation/reaction temperatures under a hydrogen flow of 30 SLPH and 15 bar. The catalytic activity data for WTi after the activation at 623 K and 673 K in term of conversion, isomerization, and cracking are presented in Table 7 . After the activation at 623 K, the domain catalytic reaction of n-heptane is the β-scission, even at the low reaction temperature. The same catalytic behavior was observed at all reaction temperatures after the activation at 673 K except at 548 K and 523 K; the conversion was sharply decreased to 68.5% and 36.7% with an improvement in the isomerization selectivity of 54.0% and 73.1%, respectively (Table 7). In both cases, C3/iC4 ≈ 1.0 at all reaction temperatures, which means that C3 and iC4 products were produced from the same source of β-scission. The only exception to this is at 673 K, where C3/iC4 = 2.2, in which case at high temperature, C3 was produced from hydrogenolysis in addition to β-scission. This catalytic behavior could be explained from the possible catalytic reactions of nC7 as demonstrated in Scheme 1: there are two possible routes to form carbenium ions. The first possibility is that carbenium ions formed on acidic sites after the dehydrogenation of nC7 to nC7 = on metallic sites. The second possibility is that the carbenium ions formed from the carbonium ions generated on strongly acidic sites. At the activation temperature of 623 K with a low M/A ratio (strong acidic properties), the iC7 carbenium ions are converted to iC4, nC4, and C3, and the catalytic reaction pathway is (3), (5) and (8). At the activation at 673 K with the increase of the M/A ratio, the iC7 carbenium ions preferred deprotonation to iC7=. Subsequently, iC7 = hydrogenated on metallic sites to iC7 especially at the low reaction temperature, and the preferable catalytic reaction pathway is (1), (2), (5), (6) and (7). The catalytic reaction pathway of n-heptane on WTi changed completely when WTi was activated at 723 K or 773 K (Table 8 ). Hydrogenolysis is the dominant catalytic reaction in which C1-C6 products are obtained even at low conversion. This catalytic behavior could be attributed to the increases of the metallic sites with deceases in the acidic sites at high activation temperatures, where the hydrocracking reaction are more favorable on the metallic sites. In this case, the favorable catalytic reaction pathway of n-heptane is (1), (2), and (4) (Scheme 1). The catalytic activity was decreased abruptly to 51.6% and 27.1% compared to 97.1% and 92.0% at the reaction temperature of 598 K and 573 K when WTi is activated at 773 K and 673 K, respectively. 3.3.2 Effect of hydrogen flow rate The effect of hydrogen flow on the catalytic reaction pathway of n-heptane was studied at a different hydrogen flow values in the range of 5–60 SLPH over WTi activated at 673 K (Fig. 10 ). At the reaction temperature of 573 K, 0.8 h−1 LHSV and 15 bar, it was observed that when the hydrogen flow increased from 5 to 60 SLPH, both conversion and β-scission decreased while isomerization increased, even though the amount of hydrogenolysis products remained the same. When the hydrogen flow increases, the contact time between the carbenium ion and the acidic sites on the surface of activated WTi decreases, decreasing the amount of β-scission products and showing an improvement in the isomerized products. In other words, at high hydrogen flow (short contact time), β–scission decreases due to the high deprotonation of the iC7 carbenium ion to iC7 = on acidic sites that subsequently hydrogenate on the metallic sites to produce iC7 (reaction pathway 6,7 Scheme 1). 4 Conclusion XPS investigation confirms the formation of acidic, metallic and functional (metal-acid) sites on the surface of WTi after activation with hydrogen at different temperatures. The strength and distribution of these sites depend on the activation temperature. Before activation, WTi has strong Brønsted acidic sites, and its activation at 623 K and 673 K resulted in the formation of bifunctional sites in the form of W3-x(OH)y, while its activation at 773 K resulted in the formation of strong metallic sites, as observed from the hydrogenolysis products of n-heptane. The isomerization of n-hexane to high octane number products is the favorable reaction on the activated WTi at 673 K, whereas β-scission is the dominant catalytic reaction for the activation temperature of 623 K. However, β-scission is the favorable reaction for n-heptane over WTi activated at 623 K and 673 K. Moreover, hydrogenolysis is the dominant catalytic reaction of n-heptane over activated WTi at 723 K and 773 K. Activated WTi at 673 K shows high stability in time on stream for the hydroisomerization/hydrocracking of n-hexane. Controlling the activation temperature enables the design of the active sites on the WTi surface. Activated WTi in the form of W3-x(OH)y/TiO2 can function as a hydroisomerization/hydrocracking catalyst for n-hexane and fluid cracking catalyst (FCC) for n-heptane depending on the reaction conditions. coredata.dc:description: WO3/TiO2(WTi) composite was prepared via an environmentally friendly, fast and facile wet impregnation method using distilled water as the solvent. The catalyst composite was investigated by in-situ XPS-UPS and ex-situ BET and XRD characterization techniques before and after the activation under hydrogen flow. The activation of the composite resulted in the formation of metallic and acidic catalytic sites in the form of WO3-x(OH)y on the surface of the WTi composite. The distribution of these sites depends on the activation temperature. XPS results show the formation of a different oxidation state of tungsten after its activation. The formation of WO3-x with metallic properties was confirmed by an examination of the density of states in the valence band region. On the other hand, the Brønsted acidic sites were attributed to the OH group observed in the XPS peak fitting of the O1 s peak at 531.4 eV. The catalytic activity was evaluated for the hydroisomerization/hydrocracking of n-hexane and n-heptane using 15 cm3 WTi in a large-scale reactor at different experimental parameters. At a reaction temperature of 598 K, the catalytic activity was 97.1% in the case of n-heptane in favor of β-scission (C3-iC4, 78.4%), compared to 76.1% activity in favor of the isomerization products (84.6%) in the case of n-hexane after the composite activation at 673 K. The research octane number (RON) was improved from 24.8 for n-hexane to the 70–80 range for hexane isomers and from zero in the case of n-heptane to cracking products with a high octane number. Upon increasing the activation temperature to 773 K, the hydrogenolysis of n-heptane was the dominant catalytic reaction.
coredata.dc:title: Semi-industrial studies of Tungsten-based catalyst for hydroisomerization/hydrocracking of n-hexane and n-heptane
